body.raw:
Email marketing is a powerful marketing channel that uses email to promote your business products or services. Email marketing is a form of marketing that can make the customers on your email list aware of new products, discounts, and other services.

Here I will teach you how to create an HTML email with Maizzle and TailwindCSS.

## 1. Create New Project

To create a new project it's quite easy, you can look at the [Maizzle Documentation](https://maizzle.com/docs/installation) like the code below :

```javascript
npx degit maizzle/maizzle "your-project-name"
```

then `cd "your-project-name"` and `npm install`

## 2. Edit your Email using Tailwind CSS

You can start a development local server that watches in localhost with :

```javascript
npm run dev
```

Maizzle already has a built in template that you can use, you can use it as your starter template.

![localhost maizzle](https://dev-to-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/articles/0c83p0m69uk6ej731a4f.JPG)

#### Notes:

HTML email structure use `table`, `tr` and `td` as layout. The idea is same as CSS Grid, every column behave like Grid which you can adjust the width using Tailwind `class="w-1/2 sm:w-full"`

## 3. Link image with imagekit.io

When using Email HTML often you need to put an image on the email. Since Email HTML doesn't support image assets, you can get the image by hosting your image online. Here I use [imagekit.io]() to host my image. Simply upload and get the URL of the image to put in the src image tag then you are done. Don't forget to reduce the size since it opened between the length of an email.

## 4. Production

Build production ready to send HTML emails that have inlined CSS and many other optimizations, by running the following command:

```javascript
npm run build
```

You can view the result of build production in **_Build Production folder_**. Then copy and paste the HTML code to be ready to send to the email receiver.

![Build Production Maizzle](https://dev-to-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/articles/4ipbww82fxbg72nt6al4.JPG)

## 4. Send your first html email.

Send your first HTML Email with [Insert HTML by Designmodo](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/insert-html-by-designmodo/bcflbfdlpegakpncdgmejelcolhmfkjh) extension google chrome.

![HTML Email Designmodo](https://dev-to-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/articles/fb3gi06e4h4lt1ae7e3v.JPG)

title: 4 Tips Improving Large Contentful Paint in NextJS
summary: Fastest your LCP webpage with this strategy

body.raw:
[Largest Contentful Paint](https://web.dev/lcp/) or LCP is the time during the page load process when the largest page element is rendered within viewport. LCP is one of three charateristic
measure of core web vital Google uses as part of its search rankings, along with
[Comulative Layout Shift](https://web.dev/cls/)
and
[First Input Delay](https://web.dev/fid/).

![LCP RofiReza](https://ik.imagekit.io/rofireza/Blog/lCP_rofireza_ExtOAUpvR.jpg?ik-sdk-version=javascript-1.4.3&updatedAt=1662420126178)

### 1. Preload LCP Images

Preload the LCP image helps it load faster because the browser will just process it normally as it's encountered in the markup.
To achive this in Next js you can set Image component [priority='true'](https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next/image#priority) more see the [docs](https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next/image#priority)

```javascript
<Image
    priority={true}
    src="me.png"
    alt="Picture of the author"
    width={500}
    height={500}
/>
```

When true, the image will be considered high priority and preload. Lazy loading is automatically disabled for images using priority. Its also posible to priority more than one image

### 2. Use modern image formats (WebP, AVIF).

Out of the box NextJS Image component support
Webp Image format, but if you want to use AVIF format You can enable AVIF support with the following configuration.

    ```javascript
    module.exports = {
        images: {
            formats: ['image/avif', 'image/webp'],
        },
    }
    ```

> Note: AVIF generally takes 20% longer to encode but it compresses 20% smaller compared to WebP. This means that the first time an image is requested, it will typically be slower and then subsequent requests that are cached will be faster.

### 3. Serve correctly sized images using srcset.

Serve correctly sized images using srcset.
w stand for width

    The srcset attribute doesn't replace the src attribute. Instead the srcset attribute complements the src attribute. You still need to have a valid src attribute, but now the browser can replace its value with one of the options listed in the srcset attribute.

    The browser won't download the larger images unless they're needed. That saves bandwidth.

    using Imagekit don worry about scrset 5. Provide blur-up placeholders.
    Using blur placeholder give full know that the image is fully loaded. meanwhit the original image is still downloaded

### 4. Use Image Blur Placeholder

    Blur Placeholder is use while the image is loading. Next JS Build in Image placeholder when you use from static image.
    For dynamic images, you must provide the blurDataURL property. Solutions such as Plaiceholder can help with base64 generation.[Post](https://rofireza.com/posts/creating-blur-placeholder-images-using-NextJS-and-Plaiceholder)

    ```javascript
    <Image
        src="me.png"
        alt="Picture of the author"
        width={500}
        height={500}
        placeholder="blur"
        blurDataURL={base64BlurImage}
    />
    ```

### 5. CDN Image yours Image

Using Image Kit.io
